title: 'I'm braving The X Factor because of my late brother'
text:
It’s late June and I’m seated in a waiting room of a Regency-style building just around the corner from Harley Street. It’s standard practice for any contestant competing on The X Factor to be assessed by a healthcare professional. Working in the TV industry for more than three decades means nothing and I don’t get a pass.

“You can go up now,” says the receptionist. Three staircases later, I’m greeted by the warm smile of a psychiatrist. She quickly cuts to the chase.

“I have just one question for you,” she says. “Why?” My reply is simple: “Why not?” She looks down at the forms I’ve completed. “You were born in… ’63…”

It feels like she’s going to opt for that safe haven of all diagnoses – the...
description: It’s late June and I’m seated in a waiting room of a Regency-style building just around the corner from Harley Street.
